results.title: You Might Think You're Superior (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Students of various racial groups confront the racism they deal with daily. Perhaps schools often reinforce racism rather than help fight it? After a group of black high school students witness a disturbing incident one of the students describes what she saw. She claims police blamed a black boy for breaking a window when they had no proof it was him. She said there were five white boys and 3 black boys present and even when a white lady told them it wasn’t his fault they took no notice. When the students told the principal what happened he told them not to bother because they couldn’t fight it.

results.title: Growing up on Cummera
results.creator_credit: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: May is a Yorta Yorta woman who grew up on Cummera Gunja mission. She warmly reflects on her days there, swimming and listening the the elders tell their stories. Moved away from her community, she experienced racism and prejudice but from those experiences learnt to overcome the boundries that others set up for her. She has since committed to a lifetime of learning and teaching and linking children and family back to their communities.

results.title: Who pays the price?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
One of a 3 part series on unemployment in Australia, presented by Keith Windschuttle. Examines the role of new technology in displacing people from traditional jobs. Shows how silicon chips are made, and their current and future applications in traditionally labour intensive areas such as retailing, banking and office work. Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system.

results.title: Futures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
One of a 3 part series on unemployment in Australia, presented by Keith Windschuttle. Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, and considers whether the coming mineral boom will lead to lower unemployment rates. Also looks at some of the effects that technological change has had on employment, and at a number of local community efforts to decrease unemployment in country towns. Presented by Keith Windschuttle.

results.title: The Lost generation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
Keith Windschuttle, looks at the problems of high youth unemployment as manifested in the increasing numbers of young homeless people squatting in derelict houses. Suggests that more innovations in secondary education would help prepare students for the realities of the present job market.

results.title: You can't take it with you
results.brief_description: Meet the Vanderhofs - the zaniest, happiest family ever to grace the screen. They have a simple philosophy for living “Nothing is worth doing if you can’t enjoy it - and when it’s over you can’t take it with you”. Head of this eccentric clan is Grandpa, (Lionel Barrymore) who has decided to devote the rest of his life to having fun because he has enough money. Matters become complicated when his granddaughter (Jean Arthur) falls in love with James Stewart, son of a tycoon (Edward Arnold), who wants the Vanderhof property to expand his business. Wholesome, homespun, appealing and touching this screwball Capra comedy won two Academy Awards in 1938 for Best Picture and Best Direction.

results.title: The Things we want to keep
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Malcolm Otton, Australian Heritage Commission and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Looks at many of Australia’s historic buildings, towns, aboriginal sites, parks, flora and fauna. Shows some of the restoration work that has been done and encourages people to be aware of their heritage and to start thinking about change and the environment.

results.title: The Work That Was. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Who Pays the Price? (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system. “Futures” (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, unemployment in country towns, and the prospects of the coming mineral boom.

results.title: Childhood memories of Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a tribute to her mother, the Indigenous activist Eleanor Harding, Deborah Deacon tells of her life and various struggles. Wanting a better life for her family was the main motivation in Eleanor moving from her home in Queensland to Melbourne. She eventually found a community in Fitzroy who supported her when she needed it at the start. Eleanor never forgot this, and devoted her life to helping out the community in various ways throughout her life. Her mother, as well as the elders of her community, have instilled in Deborah a strong sense of both individual and community empowerment.
